This is my first private beta in SE and I feel that this topic needs some solid rules regarding tags, seeing as how broad they can get. I propose to break down every topic into "fields". Some possible fields would be:
- **Science** (possibly break this one down, ie physics, chem etc)
Examples: How does electricity work? How does the Sun heat the Earth?
- **Technology**
Examples: How does data get written to a CD? How do computers display video?
- **Mechanics**
Examples: How do cars use fuel? How do pulleys work?
These are the main ideas I can come up with right now, but I'm sure more will come. Hopefully this will keep the tags clean and make subscribing via RSS worth it for more people.
Maybe even break down those sections into subsections ie: mechanics-cars, technology-hardware

The "perfect answer" that I see to a question like that would include a short summary of how it works (while answering any little questions the user has), followed by a link to howstuffworks.com or any other links that will go into more detail.
I agree that a lot of the content that is going to be asked here can be found somewhere on the net, but I think our goal is trying to bring everything together with good moderation and explain to the user "how it works" while giving them the correct path to go down.

I think having "How does" will be a good boost for SEO purposes... Maybe it's repetitive but it *is* a "how things work" site, and if the question titles almost exactly match what people are typing into Google, this will probably help drive traffic to the site quite rapidly.
I do think that when asking questions, we should try to consider other title structures though. "What is the mechanics behind...?", "What causes *X* to work like *Y*?", etc. But I do think they should remain as questions... IMHO anyway.

I think that our target audience should be anyone who is curious about how various things work. I.E. the normal person.
Having said that, rules to follow for good topics would be topics that can be answered to some level of detail, but not so much detail as to overload the standard user's attention span.
Further, we should also be asking about how we should answer questions. Good answers should be fairly to-the-point, while providing a decent level of detail. Answers which do not include enough information to adequately answer the question (such as "Go google it" or "This page here explains how it works: <link>", but not actually providing details in the answer about how something works) should be considered "Not a good answer" or a very very low-quality answer.
As to who we should consider "experts", i believe we should break it down into various categories. Such categories could be:
- Electronics Experts (electronics repair people, for example) - Computer Experts (computer technicians, for example) - Engineering Experts (engineers) - Automobile experts (automobile repair people, people who build/design automobiles, etc. for automobile questions [I noticed a few of them already])
Of course, the above list is NOT all inclusive. For example, I might be considered a Computer Expert, as I am a computer technician who can answer questions regarding how computers and their hardware work (to some extent).

One of the strengths of Stack Exchange is that it can answer those detailed, long-tailed questions with a high degree of credibility and confidence; That the question can be answered objectively by someone who has personal or expert experience with that exact problem; That you don’t have to read through a lot of discussion to find the best answer, and that someone else can embellish it and make it even better. With most Stack Exchange sites, we expect questions to represent real problems, not just imponderables, hypotheticals, or requests for opinions.
**Those are the criteria.** That's what makes a good Stack Exchange site; Better than any other.
But if this site is going to become an endless list of:
> Question: How does [common object] work? > > Answer: According to HowStuffWork and Wikipedia [common object] works by [rehashed description…]
…there really *isn't* much use to this site.
Consider for a moment — A private beta is where you finally apply the rudaments of the proposal to decide "what is the purpose of this site?" You have to ask yourself, how are we going to use this engine and this community to create a canonical source of expert answers better than any other on this subject? Ask yourself how are you going to carry forward Stack Exchange's primary mission:
###*"Make the Internet a better place to get expert answers to your questions"*

I think the question is best answered by determining if you want to know *how an object or technology works* verses *what the mechanics behind an actual physics subject are*. For example, I asked [how powerline technology works](http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/67/20) and I did say I am interested in what actually happens to the electrical current. So I do want a technical, physics explanation. However I am asking about the *technology* of Ethernet over Powerline, *not* the academic subject of electricity. So I believe it's on-topic here and not at physics.stackexchange.com.
Put another way: If you want to know *how something works*, ask here. If you want *the mathematics behind a physical reaction or the scientific explanation of something*, ask on http://physics.stackexchange.com. You could *almost* compare it to SuperUser verses StackOverflow: If it's a general questions about computers or how to make them do things, ask on SuperUser. If you want a computer science answer about programming ask on StackOverflow.

True, you could write a book on *anything*... But you don't necessarily need to *read* a book to get the answer you're looking for. I can probably get a satisfactory answer to "How does a toaster oven work?" without reading pages of formula on kinetic theory...
However, the myriad monetary systems that exist or have existed are not a toaster oven. I doubt the author of that question *really* wanted an in-depth study on current theories of monetary economics - he probably just wanted a reasonably accurate summary of how monetary value is maintained in whatever system he happens to be a part of. If that's even on-topic here (and as I said, it *should be debated*), it must be specific - to twist my toaster oven example, would you *really* want to answer, "How does heat work?"

I envision a site describing how the world and the objects we relate to every day work, as opposed to concepts about society, politics, economics, etc.
In my experience a more narrow focus makes for a better StackExchange site.

> # Summary: > ## I think we need to ask *very specific questions* > ###That way, we provide a resource which HowStuffWorks or Wikipedia can not
# TL;DR complete answer:
----
I agree with the concerns Joel mentioned. First and foremost, **we cannot have copyright infringement!!!** [howstuffworks.com](http://www.howstuffworks.com/) is not an open and free encyclopedia like Wikipedia and copying articles verbatim or reusing their images will not only get Stack Exchange in trouble but *it is a terrible reflection on our community and our users*.
However the point goes beyond that alone. **This is a much bigger question than just "how do we not be HowStuffWorks.com"** As Joel said, *we don't want to copy from or simply link to Wikipedia either*, even if copyright isn't a concern. I've been thinking about this a lot since reading Joel's posts, because I have a strong gut feeling that this can be a truly awesome Stack Exchange site, and I was trying to reconcile my feeling with some logical conclusions...
I have said in answers and comments that it would be fine to ask questions which have large overlap with Wikipedia. I never meant to imply that it was okay to simply copy from Wikipedia, but as a counter-argument to someone who said that [htw.stackexchange.com](http://htw.stackexchange.com/) was pointless and would just end up mirroring [howstuffworks.com](http://www.howstuffworks.com/) or Wikipedia, I did say,
> Why even have this site when others like it exist? Because if you're not a Stack Exchange site than you're doing it wrong!!! StackExchgange FTW!
Clearly that was a playful comment, but at the same time **it's so much more**. I truly believe in the Stack Exchange model, and I do believe that this site has a genuine purpose even when we also have Wikipedia. So I tried to think about *what it was specifically* that makes me love Stack Exchange sites more than Wikipedia.
1. **It's the voting system**
I've been using the internet since before some of our users were born. I've been programming for even longer than that. So I've been asking people for help with programming problems for *a long time*, and *nowhere* have I found better answers than StackOverflow. Plus, SO gives better answers *faster* than anywhere else. And the same thing goes for ServerFault, SuperUser, and just about all the SE sites I use. The voting system makes the cream rise to the top. But it's more than that alone...
1. **It's the reputation system**
In the "dark days" of the internet before Stack Exchange, on forums, listservs and BBS systems before those, there just wasn't that much incentive to put time and effort into helping people. The reputation system changes that, it makes people strive to take ownership of the site and really help each other by answering questions, editing questions, and building the best site possible. But, Wikipedia does an amazingly good job of being collaboratively edited with no reputation system...
1. **It's the *community***
You can't ask Wikipedia anything. I'm sure the editors and authors for Wikipedia have a sense of community and chat or talk amongst themselves somehow, but to me (and I assume a majority of others) *wikipedia is an encyclopedia, and not a community*. Having used StackOverflow from before SuperUser or ServerFault even existed, I can say I am **overwhelmed** at how the experience has changed in the past year. Chat has a *giant* part to do with this. Maybe I'm just biased because I'm the #2 chat user on Meta, but, I think that chat has really made this place a great community of users.
### So what does this mean?
What it means to me is that we need to put our strengths to use. Since we're a community and not just an encyclopedia, we have strengths Wikipedia doesn't. We can ask each other for much more analytical and in-depth knowledge that sure, maybe Wikipedia *has* but a *human being* has to gather from a wikipedia article and assimilate.
**I think that this site can really excel with very specific, long-tail questions**.
> How does *x* work?
Can just be explained by reading the entire Wikipedia article. But if we start to ask,
> How does *x* do *y*?
or
> Why is *x* better at *y* than *z*?
We're now asking for specific information which maybe is in the Wikipedia article, but you'd need to read the entire article to find the specific part. It's like on StackOverflow, if you ask a specific question, you get specific answers. But if you just ask "How do I make code which does *x?*" you get closed.
Questions should be extremely specific, and not ask for an overview of how an entire thing or technology works; instead, questions should be long-tailed and ask how one particular part of a thing or technology works.
**Here's some good, specific question examples:**
* http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/152/20 * http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/10/20 * http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/11/20 * http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/20/20
The first example is not just "How does a trolley work?" but rather it's asking about a *very specific problem*. Trolley or traffic signals or cars are complicated machines... asking about a specific thing is much easier than reading an entire article on everything about them just for one piece of information.
**Compare the above to these much broader questions:**
* http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/148/20 * http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/202/20 * http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/206/20 * http://htw.stackexchange.com/q/8/20
I'm not saying these are bad questions. **I'm just saying these are the kind of questions which can get us into trouble**. "How does a nuclear reactor work?" is **so broad** that you really are better off reading the entire Wikipedia article. It would be like asking on StackOverflow "How does Facebook work?" -- it'll get closed in an instant. But if you ask about a specific part of Facebook, you're likely to get a specific and very interesting answer.

What makes a good question in my opinion?
- Needs to be about an object not about a concept. - Has to be focused around how something works or asking how 2 things work and comparing them - Shouldn't be easy to find in a google search/article, there needs to be a reason why you asked it here. - Should allow for a rich and deep explanation.
So do we have any examples of good questions currently? Yes, we do and here's why I think they're good.

Why is overlap a problem. You can have questions that can be answered targeted to a difference audience. For some people specialized sites might give answers that are to details, to specialized, and do not meet the needs of the person who is looking for an answer.

A user has been answering a lot of questions. In one particular case, his answer was factually incorrect in several places, poorly worded, poorly spelt and poorly referenced. I began to edit his post but ended in answering the question again separately because there was too much to change - I did also comment on his own response but it's already been accepted by the original question asker, so at least one person has accepted an incorrect reply (which is what worried me initially).
He's also answered other questions seemingly without verifying the information he's posting and is in danger of promulgating incorrect information and watering down the accuracy of the knowledge on HTW. How can we best gently remind him to double- and triple-check his answers prior to submitting them?
I don't wish to come down too hard on him as the kid's apparently only 15 - if he went and answered every question with "almost-right" information in a science exam he'd be rightly marked down so I don't see why he should be given leeway to do the same on here.

I think that a vital part of this sites success is going to be the following element which is mentioned in the StackExchange FAQ on many a site:
> It’s also perfectly fine to ask and answer your own question, as long as you pretend you’re on Jeopardy: phrase it in the form of a question.
I think that it would be helpful if folks would ask questions that they *know* the answers to so that they can go ahead give a solid answer. At least for the private beta, so we can get a solid foundation here.
Additionally, citations are important here. While copying and pasting content from others is wrong and lowers the quality of the site, providing factual information requires some sort of backing.
This site is only going to succeed if it is heavily defined by the beta participants. We need to lead by example.

If you have found a user who is a serious problem, for example they are being offensive or posting hateful or damaging content, or SPAM, then posting here to bring attention to the team so that they can handle it may be appropriate, though you should first flag for moderator attention and leave a detailed description of the problem there.
But in general, the answer to "How to deal with a user with poor quality answers?" is *the same way as on any other Stack Exchange site:*
1. Downvote bad questions or incorrect answers. 1. Comment on bad posts with why they're bad. 1. Edit bad posts to correct them 1. Flag seriously low quality posts for moderator attention
And the community will take care of it.

It seems like the biggest problem facing "how things work" is identifying ways this site can [actually][1] [make][2] [the][3] [inter][4][net][5] [better][6] instead of just duplicating or linking to other, better sites--and slowing down users in the process as Joel put it so well.
What I would like to see is a list of the good, solid questions which show "how things work" doing this. Answers are good too, but the idea is that the whole package of what's happening demonstrates something that "how things work" does better than anyplace else. I don't know how to set this question up as the fancy wikified ones I've seen on other Stack Exchange meta's, but links with reasons and possibly relevant excerpts will do fine, or perhaps someone else can set it up.
Are there tangible examples of "how things work" doing things right? Let's see them!

_Prologue_
Well-I guess I've been fairly active on this site and provided quite a few answers here and there. And I enjoyed messing around here with my free time more than I do in other places such as SU...
_But is this going to last long?_
I've been to the atheism site during the beta and enjoyed the time while it lived... The problem with the site is that there are just so many question people could ask in a site- and it turns out that there are not so many!
I hope that this site is not going to repeat many of the failed proposals... but then there are just not so many things in the world that its inner working is untrivial, interesting and is the question count going to plateau soon? I surely am worried... (Also see below)
I don't have the hard numbers but from eyeballing it seems that question numbers has not been growing as fast as it has been... maybe some admin could tell us more about it...
_Hey, but one can ask for example thousands of untrivial question on how certain X work, in the field of Y..._
Yes- this site could for example turn into something that allows people to understand more on, for example, anything medically related- and perhaps, for example, I could help answer some of the question.... but this is not going to last very long as people do somehow get fed up when they (1) are real good at answering question, (2) spent too much time doing it... (I think some of our SU users would remember one of our moderator....)
The problem is, trivial question, on one hand, can be answered by just about anybody, but some of them are too trivial, and there are not so many of them (or else everything would be so trivial... eh, everybody's a genius-) and difficult, professional questions, on the other hand, could only be answered by a small group of people, who may or may not come to our site- and thus my worry.
_And then the question is... what?_
1. How do we ensure that we have a never-ending supply of question? Broadening our scope? or something else? 2. How do we distinguish this site from a simple google search // wikipedia search // etc?
_i know there are similar question but perhaps just let us take the survival problem here and discuss_
Is this site going to work very well in long-term?

The Only Thing I Want in the World: ----
Please, please, please, let's make the icon for this site be a magnet.

If I'm not mistaken, the original title for this proposed site was **Popular Science**. I personally think this was a far more appropriate name for this Q&A site, because many questions that are perfect for "Popular Science" don't fit the **How Things Work** subject. At the same time, these question are too basic or uninteresting for the **Physics** stackexchange site.
Although broadening the subject could improve things, to be honest I'm very pessimistic about the future of this site, because I haven't seen a single question that couldn't have been found in 2 minutes by doing a simple Google search.

> The problem is, trivial question, on one hand, can be answered by just about anybody, but some of them are too trivial, and there are not so many of them (or else everything would be so trivial... eh, everybody's a genius-) and difficult, professional questions, on the other hand, could only be answered by a small group of people, who may or may not come to our site- and thus my worry.
This is my concern as well. Once you get past the "quick Google search provides a few dozen perfectly good answers" questions, you're stuck trying to attract experts to a site where they may well be a tiny, tiny minority - which misses the whole idea behind SE, where you get experts in some area together to participate in answering questions.
Sure, we could be content aiming for [mediocre][1] ["everyman" answers][2] and hoping that SE Magic somehow makes that work... But then all you've done is create yet another [content farm][3]:
> CHACE: Maggio is a military wife who works from home with a Pomeranian on her lap. After looking for work for months in Fairfax, Virginia, where her husband is stationed, she decided to go back to school to get a masters degree in Psychology. She supports herself by freelance writing.
> Ms. MAGGIO: My best day I wrote 10 in about 75 minutes. So you got to figure, I made 80 bucks in 75 minutes, which is decent. I mean, that's more than I made when I was working full time.
> CHACE: It's 15 bucks an article for eHow, $8 an article for MadeMan.com, and a buck an article, plus revenue traffic, for Examiner.com.
> -- NPR's Morning Edition, *[Google Tweaks Algorithm to Spot Content Farms](http://www.npr.org/2011/04/22/135625124/google-tweak-s-algorithm-to-spot-content-farms)*
...with the same drudgery as the rest of the sites doing this, but without putting anyone through school.
> 1. How do we ensure that we have a never-ending supply of question? Broadening our scope? or something else? > 2. How do we distinguish this site from a simple google search // wikipedia search // etc?
There's no reason this site shouldn't have an endless supply of questions. New *stuff* gets developed all the time, so if the goal is to explain how it works, then that problem is solved...
...But the topic is already too broad and shallow. The solution to competing with Google/Wikipedia is *narrow and deep*, the exact opposite of where this site is headed.
